journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: A lumped parameter model for diesel soot morphology evaluation and emission control

contrib-group.aff: Department of Technologies, University of Naples ‘Parthenope’, Centro Direzionale, Naples, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Giacomo Falcucci, Department of Technologies, University of Naples ‘Parthenope’, Centro Direzionale – Isola C4, 80143 Naples, Italy. Email: giacomo.falcucci@uniparthenope.it

abstract.p: Diesel engine emission standards have become more and more severe in recent years. The use of diesel particulate filters (DPFs) is a consolidated technology to reduce the emission of particulate matter out of such engines. This work is aimed at presenting a global lumped parameter for onboard applications to estimate soot morphology and its effects on DPF performances. Starting from diesel soot production during combustion, soot morphology is evaluated in terms of fractal dimension and radii of gyration. The morphology of particulate matter influences the permeability of soot deposit inside the DPF: the growth of soot layer and the consequent pressure loss are evaluated during the loading phase in different sections of the trap. Finally, the temperature trend during regeneration is computed, as a function of the amount of soot accumulated in the different zones of the DPF. The results are compared to experimental measures from the literature and to 3D-computational fluid dynamics (3D-CFD) simulations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
During the last decade, the employment of diesel engines both on heavy- and light-duty vehicles has grown considerably all over the world, especially in Europe, where more than one-half of new passenger cars have a compression ignition engine. The main environmental concerns for diesel engines come from the production of nitrogen oxides (known as
N
O
x
) and particulate material (PM), both related to its type of combustion. Emission standards have got more and more severe in recent years, leading to great efforts to reduce pollutant production and release in the atmosphere.

Soot is a byproduct of diesel combustion,1,2 formed via a series of rapid thermal and chemical reactions in which the long-chain molecules of diesel fuel are cracked down through pyrolysis to form lighter hydrocarbons (such as acetylene,
C
2
H
2
). Hiroyasu and Kadota3 and Fusco et al.4 developed two models for the global computation of soot mass inside the combustion chamber.

The morphology of diesel soot has proven to be a crucial problem, both for its effects on human health5,6 and for its consequences on diesel trap performance.7,8 The theoretical study of soot morphology was conducted by Smoluchowski9 and Friedlander10 and enhanced by Konstandolopulos et al. in the first years of 2000,11,12 while in the literature there are many experimental works on PM characterization13–16 in terms of radii of gyration and fractal dimensions. Recently, Mosbach et al.17 developed a computationally cheap and efficient simulation code to describe soot formation and characteristics, based on a Monte Carlo population balance solver.

The effects of soot morphology on deposit characteristics and overall pressure loss were studied for wall-flow DPFs by Konstandopoulos et al.,7 by means of a global approach based on the evaluation of the exhaust gas Peclet number. Starting from the soot deposit properties, like permeability, thickness and activation energy, the temperature trends during regeneration can be predicted.18,19

In previous works,8,20 a lumped parameter model was developed to predict pressure losses during loading and temperature trends during regeneration, accounting for soot layer thickness variation along the axis of the diesel filter. The trend of deposited soot is recovered by means of 3D-CFD (computational fluid dynamics) works21,22 and experimental measures.23

In this work, a global methodology for soot evaluation is presented both in terms of mass production and morphology; the approach is zero-dimensional, in order to be suited for fast onboard diagnostics. Soot morphology for different engine loads is evaluated by means of an ad hoc developed procedure; the results are compared to the experimental measurements of the Argone National Laboratory and used to predict the characteristic of particulate deposit in different sections of the DPF.25

Since PM deposition is not homogeneous inside the filter structure (both radially and along filter length),23 the heat released during DPF regeneration may be characterized by hot spots, potentially fatal for filter substrate: the present lumped parameter (LP) model is able to follow filter temperature evolution in the different sections with a computing time scale of the order of
10
− 1
–
10
0
s, far less than the time scale of regeneration phenomena (
10
1
–
10
2
s), thus proving to be a reliable and global tool for DPF maintenance onboard strategies.
In each of the following sections, the methodology is described and the results are presented and compared to experimental works from the literature and to 3D-CFD simulations.

sec.title: Soot formation and oxidation
sec.p: The evolution of soot inside the combustion chamber is deeply influenced by several factors, such as fuel type, air/fuel ratio, temperature and exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) rate, as well as by the spray evolution in the combustion chamber.2 The present soot model is derived from that proposed by Bayer and Foster,28 and it is based on a modified version of the equations by Hiroyasu and Kadota.3 The first step is to determine spray characteristics and penetration, then the evolution of soot mass is evaluated.

The spray angle
θ
is given by

The penetration of the fuel before vaporization is called liquid length,
LL
, and determines the location of the rich zone where initial pyrolysis occurs

Equation (2) refers to quasi-steady flows with uniform rate, velocity, fuel concentration and temperature profile: the direct consequence of these hypotheses is the perfect mixing inside the spray boundaries. In equation (2),
B
is a function of air/fuel ratio, according to the thermodynamic conditions in the combustion chamber:
The distance between the nozzle and the most upstream location of combustion is called lift-off-length26

The lift-off-length can be used to determine the equivalence ratio
ϕ

Table 2 reports the main characteristics of the engine used in this work, Lombardini LDW1603, and the different operating conditions considered.

According to the conditions in Table 2, the results of soot mass evolution inside engine combustion chamber are reported in Figure 1. Figure 1 shows the comparison between the soot evolution inside each of the cylinders, as predicted by the LP model and computed by AVL BOOST, a commercial code for 0–1D simulation of internal combustion engines.29 The matching between the trends and magnitudes is quite good and highlights the accuracy of the LP model in evaluating the total amount of soot produced in the different engine operating conditions.

caption.p: Soot mass evolution: (a) comparison between LP predictions and AVL-BOOST results for soot mass evolution as a function of engine crank angle; (b) the scattered plot highlights the good match between LP predictions and AVL-BOOST results in all working conditions according to Table 2. LP: lumped parameter.

sec.title: Soot morphology
sec.p: According to soot morphology, it is important to investigate both primary particle diameters and aggregate dimensions. Primary particle growth, in fact, is directly related to the total amount of soot emission, while the dimension of the aggregates have an influence on human health6 and DPF performance.33

In experimental activities conducted at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL),15 the sizes of primary particles were measured by means of a digital image processing system at different engine operating conditions. Figure 2 sketches diesel particulates, which were found to be stretched chain-like aggregates of primary aggregates (called primary particles), which can be considered as spherical.11,15,30 The characterization of the aggregate is done in terms of the radius of gyration, which has proven to give more detail than the aerodynamic diameter,15 and the fractal dimension, which is related to the level of complexity of soot shape. The radius of gyration of an aggregate as that represented in Figure 2 is computed by means of

where
r
i
is the distance between the centre of a primary particle and the centroid of the associated aggregate and
n
is the number of primary particles within a single aggregate, which is given by

) of an aggregate represents the ramification of fractal characteristics of complex aggregates of particles and it is commonly used to standardize the complex shape of diesel particulates. It is defined as

In our work, there is no need to consider the restructuring of diesel particulates, since the residence time in the combustion chamber is smaller than 20 ms, the transitional time after which restructuring leads to appreciable variation in soot morphology.11 Once the fractal dimensions are computed, the radius of gyration is retrieved by a simple manipulation of equation (15). The radius of gyration of the particles determines the permeability of soot deposit inside a DPF.7,8 In fact, aggregate particle motion against a filter surface is characterized through the local Peclet number

As emerges from the works of Lee et al.,15,30,31 the exhaust temperature (that is, the engine load) is a major factor to influence soot morphology. In our work, temperature is given among the results of AVL BOOST simulations and is the same as given by Lee et al.15 for the different regimes. The computed values are in line with those obtained with similar EGR values for all the different operating conditions in Table 2. The fractal dimensions displayed in Figure 3 are used to compute the radii of gyration of the aggregates through equation (14). The results are reported in Figure 4. Figure 4 highlights that the data obtained are in good agreement with those measured at ANL for the different operating conditions. The dotted line represents the quadratic interpolation proposed by Lee et al.15 to interpolate their experimental results. These values are also in line with other data in the literature.7,11,30,31 In addition, it is shown that the LP prediction follows with good agreement the trend proposed by Lee et al. for the variation of the radius of gyration of an aggregate with the exhaust temperature.15 From the morphological data obtained, by means of equations (16) to (23), it is possible to pass from particulate micro-scale to soot deposit scale. sec.title: DPF loading
sec.p: For the loading and regeneration processes, a SiC DPF with the characteristics in Table 4 was considered. First, a single channel of the DPF is considered. Figure 5 shows the domain realized by means of GAMBIT code;37 thanks to the symmetrical properties of the filter monolith, a single quarter of the channel is considered. The CFD simulation is performed in the FLUENT environment. FLUENT38 code solves the following equations

which are, respectively, the equations for mass, momentum and energy conservation. In the above equations,

caption.p: Sketch of filter structure at inlet side (left); 3D computational domain realized in GAMBIT environment (right).

sec.p: The solver is set as steady state (which means that the governing equations do not contain time-dependent terms) and segregated (that is, the governing equations are solved sequentially, segregated from one another). Since governing equations are non-linear and coupled, the solution loop must be carried out iteratively in order to obtain a converged numerical solution.38

The 3D simulation reveals that the pressure drop across the filter wall along the channel is not homogeneous, as shown in Figure 7(a). This suggests that the soot layer during the deposition processes over the filter wall follows the pressure drop trend, thus growing with a
U
-shaped profile.22–24 In order to follow soot growth and its profile, a convenient division of channel length is sketched in Figure 6: the inlet and outlet section (representing
~ 15 %
of total length each) represent the high
Δ
P (high deposition zones), while the middle section (
~
70 %
of filter length) is the lower
Δ
P (lower deposition zone). Soot layer thickness in each of the three zones in Figure 6 can be calculated considering the pressure drop in each of the sections and retrieving the passing-though velocity across the filter porous wall according to Darcy’s law

caption.p: Sketch of DPF channel with the three zones representing high–low–high deposition

Figure 7(a) and (b) reports pressure drops along filter channel evaluated by means of the LP model, as compared to those found in 3D-CFD simulations. The figure highlights the good match between the values and trends in all the different operating conditions reported in Table 2. In Table 5 the PM rates and loading period durations are reported; the concentrations of PM in exhaust gas for the different operating conditions are those computed section ‘Soot formation and oxidation’. Considering the axis-symmetric structure of the whole DPF device, the above-presented model can be enhanced by considering the radial distribution of soot, besides the axial loading discussed in the previous sections. Exhaust gas velocity is not homogeneous at DPF inlet, as shown by Figure 8: two radial zones are considered, namely A and B, in which gas velocity is maximum and very close to the minimum (the minimum value would be influenced by boundary layers, which are not considered at the filter inlet section). In the following, we will analyse the loading of the DPF along its channels in the two radial sections considered: in this way, it is possible to monitor PM deposition and regeneration in nine zones of the filter, which turn into six for symmetry, as highlighted by Figure 9.

DPF loading conditions: engine speed and load, PM concentration in the exhaust gas and loading duration.

sec.p: Table 6 reports the soot thickness computed according to the above equations and the loading conditions in Table 5: only the values in zones 3 and 6 are reported, since they are the most charged, as is also known from the literature.22–24

caption.p: Comparison between soot thickness in the different zones along the filter channel computed by means of LP model and 3D-CFD simulations.

fn.p: CFD: computational fluid dynamics; LP: lumped parameter.

sec.p: The data in Table 6 highlight the good match in the different loading conditions between the predictions performed by the LP model and the values computed through CFD simulations in the final part of the structure, which is known to be the most thermally stressed.23,24,39–40

sec.title: DPF regeneration
sec.p: The last part of this work deals with the results in terms of temperature evolution prediction during the regeneration process of the loaded trap: our system is, thus, non-continuously regenerating.42 In this work, soot is considered to be composed of carbon and no catalytic contribution to filter regeneration is accounted for. In this way, the chemical reactions considered are
The evolution of soot thickness along the channel is evaluated by means of

where
K
the , i
is the thermal reaction rate for soot oxidation in the
i
th section of the filter channel and is given by35
The temperature is set to be the same at each time step for exhaust gas, filter wall and soot layer. The temperature increase is given by20

in which
m

represents the mass of soot burnt in the

c

is the specific heat capacity of ceramic wall (1120 J/(kgK))43,44 and
c

is the specific heat capacity of exhaust gas (1090 J/(kg K)).43,44 The regeneration is performed with the engine running at 1650 rpm with exhaust temperature at 860 K, which are typical conditions for non-continuous regeneration.45 The corresponding mass flow rate is
2 . 778
×
10
− 2
kg/s. Figure 10 highlights the temperature trends in section 6 of the filter (see Figure 9), which is the most charged, as highlighted by Table 6.

caption.p: Comparison between the temperature values predicted by LP model and experimental measures:45 (a) comparison of temperature evolutions for 5 g/l and 10 g/l loaded filters; (b) the scattered plot highlights the good match between LP predictions and experimental measures for the various loadings considered.LP: lumped parameter.

sec.p: Figure 10 highlights the good match between LP predictions and experimental measures reported by Hinterberger et al.45 The LP model is accurate both in predicting trends and magnitudes of temperature evolution.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, a LP model to investigate soot evolution inside the combustion chamber of diesel engines, particulate accumulation and growth and final oxidation in non-catalyzed DPFs is presented. For different engine operating conditions, the present model makes it possible to account for soot morphology, which deeply influences both the physical properties of particulate deposit inside the filter and heat release during regeneration.

By means of comparisons with experimental data in the literature and 3D-CFD simulations, the present LP model has proven to be a reliable tool to predict in real time the amount of soot, the pressure drop along the filter channel and soot layer characteristics, like thickness, permeability and packing density.

The LP model predicts in real time the expected temperature trend during DPF regeneration, as a function of engine operating conditions and particulate layer characteristics. Such a model, then, has proven to be a reliable tool to improve the strategies for onboard DPF management.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

fn.label: Future work
fn.p: Further analysis is in progress with special focus on adsorption/desorption of soluble organic fractions (SOFs) on soot particles and the effect these phenomena have on PM morphology and heat release during regeneration.

Such investigation is being carried out by means of the lattice Boltzmann method,47 a numerical approach based on Boltzmann’s kinetic equation which has been recently adopted with success in the simulation of phenomena of technical interest, especially in the field of multiphase systems.48–50
